CONFLICT.deftext:
a struggle, battle, quarrel, clash

CONFLICT comes from a Latin word which means “a striking together.” A CONFLICT is a situation in which people, nations, events, or interests disagree or interfere with one another. It could be as major as a war or battle.

“During the CONFLICT ten thousand soldiers lost their lives.”

Or a CONFLICT could be minor.

“She had a CONFLICT between Math and English. Both classes met at the same time.”

CONFLICT is also a verb, meaning to clash or disagree.

“Their stories of what happened CONFLICT, so who is telling the truth?”

“His latest statement CONFLICTS with several earlier statements he made.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer in the Pretest is injury. An injury may be the result of a CONFLICT, but the two words do not have the same meaning.

PROSPER.deftext:
to succeed, flourish

When someone PROSPERS he is succeeding or doing well. The word usually suggests continued and steadily increasing success. The word often suggests financial success.

“He PROSPERED in his new business.”

It can be used about other kinds of success as well.

“Our cat was sickly for a while, but with the proper medicine and a better diet he began to PROSPER.”

Things like companies or countries can also PROSPER.

“The town PROSPERED when the highway was built near it.”

Other forms of the word: PROSPERITY, n., PROSPEROUS, adj.

REAP.deftext:
to harvest, gather

To REAP is to cut down and gather in a crop, especially a crop of grain.

“They worked all day to REAP the wheat.”

In a general sense, REAP means “to get or win as a result of your work.”

“He hoped to REAP the benefits of his college education.”

“The inventor REAPED a fortune from this machine.”

CAVITY.deftext:
a hole, empty space

CAVITY is related to the word cave. A CAVITY is a hole, a hollowed-out space in a solid object. A CAVITY in a tooth is a hole caused by decay.

“In a hidden CAVITY in the wall they found a sack of gold.”

“The dentist found several CAVITIES in the child’s teeth.”

Many people pick tooth as the meaning of CAVITY on the Pretest. These people have heard the word used, but don’t know its exact meaning. A CAVITY is a hole in a tooth, not the tooth itself.

SHRIVEL.deftext:
to shrink, wither, dry up and wrinkle

To SHRIVEL is to shrink in size and become dry and wrinkled. Often something SHRIVELS because of heat.

“He threw the note into the fireplace where it SHRIVELED up as it burned.”

Or because of age or illness: “When people get very old, their skin SHRIVELS.”

“In the old book we found a SHRIVELED leaf which someone had wanted to keep.”

SHRIVEL can also be used about anything that can be said to dry up and shrink.

“His once great talent seemed to SHRIVEL with age.”

Usage: SHRIVEL is often followed by up.

SLAY.deftext:
to murder, kill

To SLAY someone is to put him to death by force, to murder him. SLAY is a literary word, more often used in print than in ordinary conversation.

“The bank guard was SLAIN by an unknown gunman.”

“The giant SLEW him with one swing of his mighty fist.”

Usage: The past tense of SLAY is SLEW. The past participle is SLAIN.

THRASH.deftext:
to beat, pound, whip; to move violently

THRASH means to beat, usually repeatedly with a stick or whip.

“In the spring he always had to THRASH the carpets with a rug beater.”

“Mr. Jones took out his anger at the world by THRASHING his dog.”

Because the idea of waving the arms about in beating something is included in THRASH, the word has also come to mean simply “to move or toss about violently.”

“In her sleep Debbie THRASHED around so much that she kicked off all her covers.”

ACQUAINTANCE.deftext:
familiarity; a person one knows slightly

To be ACQUAINTED with something is to be familiar with it. The word suggests only a slight knowledge, not a deep understanding.

“He speaks two languages very well and is ACQUAINTED with a dozen more.”

To be ACQUAINTED with a person is to know him, although usually not very well.

“I am ACQUAINTED with Bill. I have spoken to him a few times.” ACQUAINTANCE is a noun from ACQUAINT. ACQUAINTANCE is a general familiarity with something, but not a thorough knowledge.

“Ralph has some ACQUAINTANCE with legal matters, although he has never studied law.”

An ACQUAINTANCE is someone you know slightly, not quite a friend.

Other forms of the word: ACQUAINT, v., ACQUAINTED, adj.

Usage: ACQUAINTANCE, when it means familiarity, is usually followed by with.

BANQUET.deftext:
a feast, elaborate meal

A BANQUET is a large, elaborate meal attended by many people. It is usually given in honor of someone or to mark a special occasion.

“The championship football team was given a large BANQUET to celebrate their victory.”

“Five hundred people were at the BANQUET to honor Mr. Jones on his retirement.”

“When he saw all the food and drink on the table he said this wasn’t just a regular meal, it was a BANQUET.”

REDUCE.deftext:
to make less, make smaller, lessen, shrink

To REDUCE something is to make it smaller or less.

“The driver REDUCED his speed as he went around the corner.”

“Alice REDUCED her weight by going without lunch.”

“We must REDUCE the amount of money we spend.”

“The soldier’s rank was REDUCED from sergeant to corporal.”

REDUCTION is the noun from REDUCE.

“There has been a great REDUCTION in the number of mistakes since we started checking the work more carefully.”

“I will wait for a REDUCTION in the price before I buy it.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is to think that REDUCE means end. You do not end something by REDUCING it, you just make the size or amount of it smaller.

Other forms of the word: REDUCTION, n.

BLOATED.deftext:
swollen, puffed up

When something is BLOATED it is swollen beyond its normal size, usually with a liquid or gas.

BLOATED usually gives the sense of being puffed up in an unhealthy way.

“After drinking so much water she felt BLOATED.”

“Her legs became BLOATED as a result of the disease.”

Other forms of the word: BLOAT, v.

CLUTCH.deftext:
to seize, grab

To CLUTCH something is to seize it and hold on to it tightly, like a bird grasping something in its claws.

“He CLUTCHED the kitten so tightly that it tried to wriggle free.”

“The baby CLUTCHED its bottle with both hands.”

To CLUTCH at something is to try to get hold of it.

“Whenever she was frightened she would CLUTCH at her mother’s hand.”

CLUTCH is also a noun, meaning grasp or control. It is often used in the plural.

“The child was in the CLUTCHES of evil kidnappers.”

STAGGER.deftext:
to move unsteadily, totter, sway

STAGGER means to move unsteadily or to sway. Someone who is STAGGERING looks as if he is about to fall.

“The drunken man STAGGERED down the street.”

“The fighter was hit so hard by his opponent that he STAGGERED.”

When something STAGGERS you, it almost knocks you down. STAGGER can be used in this sense about news or ideas which astonish or shock.

“The news of her accident STAGGERED me.”

“Everyone was STAGGERED by the increase in the cost of living.”

Fall down is the most popular wrong answer. Someone who STAGGERS may be about to fall, but STAGGER does not mean to fall down.

COMMITMENT.deftext:
a pledge, obligation, promise

One meaning of the verb to COMMIT is to pledge or undertake.

“The governor has COMMITTED himself to lowering taxes this year.”

A COMMITMENT is something to which you are pledged, a promise.

“She forgot all about her COMMITMENT to sing in the show.”

“You made a COMMITMENT to help me move this morning. You can’t back out now.”

COMMITMENT is also the state of being COMMITTED.

“His COMMITMENT to their cause lessened when they started talking about violence.”

Other forms of the word: COMMIT, v.

DEBRIS.deftext:
ruins, rubbish, refuse

Note the pronunciation. DEBRIS is a French word and keeps its French pronunciation. DEBRIS is the scattered broken pieces of something that has fallen apart or been destroyed.

“The ground was covered with DEBRIS after the train wreck.”

“It took weeks to clean up the DEBRIS left behind by the flood.”

“After the fire there was nothing but DEBRIS where the house had once stood.”

questions.prompt: If two stories CONFLICT, are they the same?
Do most people want to PROSPER?
Does a farmer REAP corn before he plants it?
Does a balloon SHRIVEL when it is blown up?
Do most people dislike being THRASHED?
Should an auto mechanic have some ACQUAINTANCE with engines?
Is there a REDUCTION in a child's size as he grows up?
1I. Is a BLOATED face pleasant to look at?
Is it easy to CLUTCH something that is slippery?
Can a punch make a person STAGGER?
When two people get married, do they make a COMMITMENT to each other?
Could a bomb produce a lot of DEBRIS?
Quite a CONFLICT broke out between the supporters and the opponents of the king.
She PROSPERED that her students would do well on the test.
The employee received fifty dollars for his suggestion, but the company REAPED the profits.
The doctor removed a large CAVITY that was growing on his skin.
Bill started to SHRIVEL when he heard the funny story.
David SLEW the giant Goliath with a stone.
Mr. White threatened to THRASH them if they ever stole anything from his store again.
You'll have to tell me what they're saying, since I am not ACQUAINTED with their language.
The prince invited everyone to a huge BANQUET when he became king.
The politician promised to REDUCE taxes, but instead they were increased.
His stomach felt BLOATED after he ate the huge meal.
The drowning man CLUTCHED at the rope they threw to him.
Bill was STAGGERED when the boss told him he was fired.
Unless we have a firm COMMITMENT that the work will be completed by December 1st, we will not sign the agreement.
We had quite a DEBRIS when we won the championship.
